title: 114_hr598
content: The "Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes a section on the inventory of government programs. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act includes an amendment to Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code, defining a program as an organized set of activities by one or more agencies directed toward a common purpose or goal. The amendment also changes the responsibility for maintaining a website and program inventory from the Office of Management and Budget to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code, to define a program as organized activities by agencies towards a common goal. It shifts the duty of maintaining a website and program inventory to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, requiring identification of programs with over $1,000,000 in annual budget authority. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code, requiring the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to maintain a website and program inventory. Programs with over $1,000,000 in annual budget authority must be identified. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code by providing detailed information on program activities and funding for programs with over $10,000,000 in annual budget authority. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code by providing detailed information on program activities, funding, individuals served, beneficiaries, and regulations specific to the program. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code by requiring detailed information on program activities, funding, individuals served, and beneficiaries. It also includes provisions for explaining why data on individuals and beneficiaries may not be provided and discussing measures to gather such data. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires detailed information on program administration, including the number of Federal employees and other individuals whose salary is paid by the Federal Government to administer or assist in program activities. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act mandates detailed program administration information, such as staffing levels, program evaluations, and financial data for each activity under the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires program information for smaller programs with annual budgets between $1,000,000 and $10,000,000, including program activities, funding amounts for current and previous years, and relevant statutes and regulations. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act mandates program details for smaller programs with budgets between $1,000,000 and $10,000,000, including program activities, funding amounts, statutes, and regulations. The program inventory must also include information on individuals served, beneficiaries receiving financial assistance, and links to evaluations and performance reviews released in the past 5 years, archived annually by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires program details for smaller programs with budgets between $1,000,000 and $10,000,000, including activities, funding amounts, statutes, and regulations. The program inventory must also include information on individuals served, beneficiaries receiving financial assistance, and links to evaluations and performance reviews released in the past 5 years. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must publish the total amount of undisbursed grant funding remaining in grant accounts for which the period of availability to the grantee has expired by February 1 of each fiscal year. SEC. 3. GUIDANCE AND IMPLEMENTATION. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will prescribe guidance by June 30, 2018, to implement the Act and its amendments, issue guidance to agencies for program activities reporting, and may issue guidance to ensure non-duplicative program inventory presentation. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance by June 30, 2018, for implementing the Act and its amendments, including program activities reporting and non-duplicative program inventory presentation. Additionally, the Director may exempt certain agencies from specific requirements and extend implementation deadlines by up to one year. The Act and its amendments must be implemented by June 30, 2019, with the possibility of extending the deadline by up to 1 year. No additional funds are authorized for the requirements of this Act and its amendments. The existing authorized amounts will be used for implementation.
